Fed governor Stephen Miran said he would relinquish his option to return to the CEA as its chairman one day after all 11 Democrats on the Senate Banking Committee asked him to resign his job as a Fed governor following the end of his term on Jan. 31.

https://t.co/xyfJs0kDaF

Miran is eligible to stay in that seat until his successor (presumably it will be Fed chair-designate Kevin Warsh) is confirmed.

Democrats had been highly critical of Miran's decision not to resign the CEA job when he became a Fed governor in September. Instead of resigning the Fed job at the conclusion of its term, Miran said Tuesday he would resign from the CEA, allowing him to remain at the Fed until Warsh is confirmed.

raw_text:
VENEZUELA SEEKS REPUTATION AS TOP OIL PRODUCER

Venezuela wants to shift its image from having the world’s largest oil reserves to being one of the highest oil-producing countries, said chief economic adviser Calixto Ortega.

Speaking at the World Government Summit in Dubai, Ortega said the country aims to be known for production, not just reserves. Output has long lagged due to mismanagement, underinvestment, and sanctions.

Ortega said Venezuela is ready for investment, with U.S. and other companies waiting for sanctions to be lifted. Oil exports rose to about 800,000 barrels per day in January, up from 498,000 in December, after the end of a U.S. oil blockade.

extraction.summary: Venezuela aims to be known as a top oil producer for production, not just reserves, with January exports rising to about 800,000 barrels per day after sanctions relief.

raw_text:
US YIELD CURVE STEEPEST IN FOUR YEARS

The gap between 2- and 10-year Treasury yields has widened to about 69 basis points, near a four-year high, as investors await the Treasury’s bond auction plans.

Long-term yields are rising on concerns about growing debt and policy shifts, while short-term yields remain steady due to Fed rate-cut expectations. The steepening curve signals mounting fiscal pressure, raising borrowing costs for the government.

Markets are watching Wednesday’s refunding announcement for clues on future debt issuance.

extraction.summary: The U.S. yield curve steepened to its widest in four years as the 2- to 10-year yield gap widened to about 69 basis points ahead of the Treasury’s refunding plans, with Fed rate-cut expectations keeping short-term yields steady.
extraction.urgency_reasoning: rule-based match
extraction.impact_reasoning: Steepening curve and debt issuance plans imply higher borrowing costs and potential broader market moves.

analysis.primary_thesis: A steeper 2‑10 curve should lift bank NIM and regional-bank equities and pressure long-duration bonds and mortgage REITs over weeks.

ticker_analyses.bear_thesis: Steepening driven by growth/borrower stress could signal credit risk.
risk_factors: auction sizes surprise, rapid risk-off, macro growth shock

ticker_analyses.relevance_reason: Mortgage REITs lose when long yields rise and MBS prices fall, hurting NAV and funding.
ticker_analyses.bull_thesis: If curve steepens from stronger growth, spreads could tighten modestly.
ticker_analyses.bear_thesis: Long yields up reduce MBS values and raise hedging/funding costs for mREITs.

ticker_analyses.bear_thesis: Rising long-term yields directly lower TLT price materially.
risk_factors: sudden flight-to-quality, large dealer balance-sheet support

ticker_analyses.bull_thesis: Wider curve should boost NII and trading revenue over coming quarters.
ticker_analyses.bear_thesis: Higher long yields can depress markets and raise funding costs in stress periods.
catalysts: NII guidance, loan growth, Treasury refunding size
risk_factors: unexpected policy shifts, credit losses, severe market volatility

sector_implications.reasoning: Steepening widens NIMs, favoring bank earnings and regional-bank equities.
Higher long yields hurt MBS valuations and mortgage-REIT earnings.

analysis.historical_context: Similar steepenings occurred during 2022 episodes and prior April steepenings; historically regional-bank ETFs often outperformed by mid-single digits in the 1–2 week window while long-bond ETFs fell several percent.
analysis.typical_market_reaction: Immediate bond selloff and equity weakness; bank stocks often lag intraday then outperform over days; long-duration bonds fall, partial rebound possible.

BREAKING: Sales of electric vehicles (EVs) in China last year hit a record 13.1 million vehicles, exceeding ICE car sales for the first time.

Sales of internal combustion engine (ICE) vehicles in China fell -13% YoY, to 12.3 million in 2025, the lowest in 15 years.

This marks the 8th consecutive annual decline. 

Since the 2017 peak, sales of ICE vehicles have fallen -49%, or -11.6 million.

It is projected that China will sell 21.2 million EVs and 4.9 million combustion engine vehicles in 2030.

The global electric vehicle race is intensifying.
